questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ In an $\text{LCR}$ series circuit, current is maximum at resonance.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Current in a purely resistive circuit can never be less than that in a series $\text{LCR}$ circuit when connected to the same voltage source.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
questions.option_b: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_c: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
questions.option_d: Both Statement I and Statement II are false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Maximum power is dissipated in a circuit containing an inductor, a capacitor and a resistor connected in series with an AC source, when resonance occurs.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Maximum power is dissipated in a circuit containing pure resistor due to zero phase difference between current and voltage.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
questions.option_c: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
questions.option_d: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ Body '$P$' having mass $M$ moving with speed '$u$' has head-on collision elastically with another body '$Q$' having mass '$m$' initially at rest. If $m \ll M$, body '$Q$' will have a maximum speed equal to '$2u$' after collision.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ During elastic collision, the momentum and kinetic energy are both conserved.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: A is correct but R is not correct.
questions.option_b: A is not correct but R is correct.
questions.option_c: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.
questions.option_d: Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.

questions.question:
This question has $\textbf{Statement I}$ and $\textbf{Statement II}$. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ A point particle of mass $m$ moving with speed $v$ collides with a stationary point particle of mass $M$. If the maximum energy loss possible is given as $f\left( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \right)$, then $f = \left( \frac{m}{M + m} \right)$.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Maximum energy loss occurs when the particles get stuck together as a result of the collision.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is true, Statement II is true; Statement II is the correct explanation of Statement I.
questions.option_b: Statement I is true, Statement II is true; Statement II is not the correct explanation of Statement I.
questions.option_c: Statement I is true, Statement II is false
questions.option_d: Statement I is false, Statement II is true.

questions.question:
$\textbf{Statement I :}$ A cyclist is moving on an unbanked road with a speed of $7 \text{ kmh}^{-1}$ and takes a sharp circular turn along a path of radius of $2 \text{ m}$ without reducing the speed. The static friction coefficient is $0.2$. The cyclist will not slip and pass the curve. ($g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^{2}$)

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ If the road is banked at an angle of $45^\circ$, the cyclist can cross the curve of $2 \text{ m}$ radius with the speed of $18.5 \text{ kmh}^{-1}$ without slipping.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below.
questions.option_a: Statement I is incorrect and statement II is correct
questions.option_b: Both statement I and statement II are true
questions.option_c: Statement I is correct and statement II is incorrect
questions.option_d: Both statement I and statement II are false

questions.question: Which of the following statements is $\textbf{FALSE}$ for a particle moving in a circle with a constant angular speed?
questions.option_a: The velocity vector is tangent to the circle.
questions.option_b: The acceleration vector is tangent to the circle.
questions.option_c: The acceleration vector points to the centre of the circle.
questions.option_d: The velocity and acceleration vectors are perpendicular to each other.

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion (A)}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason (R)}$.

$\textbf{Assertion (A) :}$ Choke coil is simply a coil having a large inductance but a small resistance. Choke coils are used with fluorescent mercury-tube fittings. If household electric power is directly connected to a mercury tube, the tube will be damaged.

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ By using the choke coil, the voltage across the tube is reduced by a factor $\left(R / \sqrt{R^2+\omega^2 L^2}\right)$, where $\omega$ is frequency of the supply across resistor $R$ and inductor $L$. If the choke coil were not used, the voltage across the resistor would be the same as the applied voltage.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: (A) is true but (R) is false
questions.option_b: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_c: Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_d: (A) is false but (R) is true

questions.question:
This question has $\textbf{Statement I}$ and $\textbf{Statement II}$. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Higher the range, greater is the resistance of ammeter.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ To increase the range of ammeter, additional shunt needs to be used across it.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is true, Statement II is true, Statement II is the correct explanation of Statement I.
questions.option_b: Statement I is true, Statement II is true, Statement II is not the correct explanation of Statement I.
questions.option_c: Statement I is true, Statement II is false
questions.option_d: Statement I is false, Statement II is true

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ An electron microscope can achieve better resolving power than an optical microscope.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ The de Broglie's wavelength of the electrons emitted from an electron gun is much less than the wavelength of visible light.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: A is false but R is true.
questions.option_b: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
questions.option_c: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
questions.option_d: A is true but R is false.

questions.question:
This question has $\textbf{Statement 1}$ and $\textbf{Statement 2}$. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

$\textbf{Statement 1 :}$ A metallic surface is irradiated by a monochromatic light of frequency $\nu > \nu_0$ (the threshold frequency). The maximum kinetic energy and the stopping potential are $K_{\max}$ and $V_0$ respectively. If the frequency incident on the surface is doubled, both the $K_{\max}$ and $V_0$ are also doubled.

$\textbf{Statement 2 :}$ The maximum kinetic energy and the stopping potential of photoelectrons emitted from a surface are linearly dependent on the frequency of incident light.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is the correct explanation of Statement 1.
questions.option_b: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true, Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1.
questions.option_c: Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true.
questions.option_d: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false.

questions.question: A parallel beam of fast moving electrons is incident normally on a narrow slit. A fluorescent screen is placed at a large distance from the slit. If the speed of the electrons is increased, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.option_a: The angular width of the central maximum will decrease.
questions.option_b: The angular width of the central maximum will be unaffected.
questions.option_c: Diffraction pattern is not observed on the screen in the case of electrons.
questions.option_d: The angular width of the central maximum of the diffraction pattern will increase.

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion (A)}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason (R)}$.

$\textbf{Assertion (A) :}$ The outer body of an aircraft is made of metal which protects persons sitting inside from lightning strikes.

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ The electric field inside the cavity enclosed by a conductor is zero.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below :
questions.option_a: Both (A) and (R) are correct but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_b: (A) is correct but (R) is not correct
questions.option_c: Both (A) and (R) are correct and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_d: (A) is not correct but (R) is correct

questions.question: A body of mass $M$ and charge $q$ is connected to a spring of spring constant $k$. It is oscillating along the $x$-direction about its equilibrium position, taken to be at $x=0$, with an amplitude $A$. An electric field $E$ is applied along the $x$-direction. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.option_a: The new equilibrium position is at a distance $\frac{qE}{2k}$ from $x=0$.
questions.option_b: The total energy of the system is $\frac{1}{2}M\omega^2 A^2 + \frac{1}{2}\frac{q^2 E^2}{k}$.
questions.option_c: The total energy of the system is $\frac{1}{2}M\omega^2 A^2 - \frac{1}{2}\frac{q^2 E^2}{k}$.
questions.option_d: The new equilibrium position is at a distance $\frac{2qE}{k}$ from $x=0$.

questions.question:
Choose the incorrect statement:

(1) The electric lines of force entering into a Gaussian surface provide negative flux.
(2) A charge '$q$' is placed at the centre of a cube. The flux through all the faces will be the same.
(3) In a uniform electric field net flux through a closed Gaussian surface containing no net charge, is zero.
(4) When electric field is parallel to a Gaussian surface, it provides a finite non-zero flux.

Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: (3) and (4) only
questions.option_b: (2) and (4) only
questions.option_c: (4) only
questions.option_d: (1) and (3) only

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ A bar magnet dropped through a metallic cylindrical pipe takes more time to come down compared to a non-magnetic bar with same geometry and mass.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ For the magnetic bar, Eddy currents are produced in the metallic pipe which oppose the motion of the magnetic bar.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: A is true but R is false
questions.option_b: A is false but R is true
questions.option_c: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
questions.option_d: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

questions.question:
A conducting bar of length $L$ is free to slide on two parallel conducting rails as shown in the figure. Two resistors $R_1$ and $R_2$ are connected across the ends of the rails. There is a uniform magnetic field $\vec{B}$ pointing into the page. An external agent pulls the bar to the left at a constant speed $v$.

The correct statement about the directions of induced currents $I_1$ and $I_2$ flowing through $R_1$ and $R_2$ respectively is:
questions.option_a: Both $I_1$ and $I_2$ are in clockwise direction
questions.option_b: $I_1$ is in clockwise direction and $I_2$ is in anticlockwise direction
questions.option_c: $I_1$ is in anticlockwise direction and $I_2$ is in clockwise direction
questions.option_d: Both $I_1$ and $I_2$ are in anticlockwise direction

questions.question: Consider an electromagnetic wave propagating in vacuum. Choose the correct statement:
questions.option_a: For an electromagnetic wave propagating in $+x$ direction the electric field is $\vec E = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } E_{yz} (x,t) (\hat y - \hat z)$ and the magnetic field is $\vec B = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } B_{yz} (x,t) (\hat y + \hat z)$
questions.option_b: For an electromagnetic wave propagating in $+x$ direction the electric field is $\vec E = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } E_{yz} (y,z,t) (\hat y + \hat z)$ and the magnetic field is $\vec B = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } B_{yz} (y,z,t) (\hat y + \hat z)$
questions.option_c: For an electromagnetic wave propagating in $+y$ direction the electric field is $\vec E = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } E_{yz} (x,t) \hat y$ and the magnetic field is $\vec B = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } B_{yz} (x,t) \hat z$
questions.option_d: For an electromagnetic wave propagating in $+y$ direction the electric field is $\vec E = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } E_{yz} (x,t) \hat z$ and the magnetic field is $\vec B = \frac{1}{\sqrt 2 } B_{z} (x,t) \hat y$

questions.question: Which of the following statements is $\textbf{FALSE}$ for the properties of electromagnetic waves?
questions.option_a: Both electric and magnetic field vectors attain the maxima and minima at the same place and same time.
questions.option_b: The energy in electromagnetic wave is divided equally between electric and magnetic vectors.
questions.option_c: Both electric and magnetic field vectors are parallel to each other and perpendicular to the direction of propagation of wave.
questions.option_d: These waves do not require any material medium for propagation.

questions.question: Two capacitors $C_1$ and $C_2$ are connected in parallel to a battery. The charge-time graph is shown below for the two capacitors. The energy stored in them are $U_1$ and $U_2$, respectively. Which of the given statements is true?

Given below are two statements: One is labeled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labeled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ Two metallic spheres are charged to the same potential. One of them is hollow and another is solid, and both have the same radii. Solid sphere will have lower charge than the hollow one.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ Capacitance of metallic spheres depend on the radii of spheres.

In light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ are true but $\mathbf{R}$ is not the correct explanation of $\mathbf{A}$
questions.option_b: Both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ are true and $\mathbf{R}$ is the correct explanation of $\mathbf{A}$
questions.option_c: $\mathbf{A}$ is false but $\mathbf{R}$ is true
questions.option_d: $\mathbf{A}$ is true but $\mathbf{R}$ is false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion (A)}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason (R)}$.

$\textbf{Assertion (A) :}$ The radius vector from the Sun to a planet sweeps out equal areas in equal intervals of time and thus areal velocity of planet is constant.

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ For a central force field the angular momentum is a constant.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: (A) is not correct but (R) is correct
questions.option_b: Both (A) and (R) are correct but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_c: Both (A) and (R) are correct and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_d: (A) is correct but (R) is not correct

questions.question:
This question contains $\textbf{Statement 1}$ and $\textbf{Statement 2}$. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements.

$\textbf{Statement 1 :}$ For a mass $M$ kept at the center of a cube of side $a$, the flux of gravitational field passing through its sides is $4\pi GM$.

$\textbf{Statement 2 :}$ If the direction of a field due to a point source is radial and its dependence on the distance $r$ from the source is given as $1/r^2$, its flux through a closed surface depends only on the strength of the source enclosed by the surface and not on the size or shape of the surface.

In light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true
questions.option_b: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is a correct explanation for Statement 1
questions.option_c: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is not a correct explanation for Statement 1
questions.option_d: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Acceleration due to gravity is different at different places on the surface of earth.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Acceleration due to gravity increases as we go down below the earth's surface.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
questions.option_c: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_d: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ The limiting force of static friction depends on the area of contact and is independent of materials.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ The limiting force of kinetic friction is independent of the area of contact and depends on materials.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
questions.option_c: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
questions.option_d: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect

questions.question:
$\textbf{Statement I :}$ If three forces $\vec F_1, \vec F_2$ and $\vec F_3$ are represented by three sides of a triangle and $\vec F_1 + \vec F_2 = - \vec F_3$, then these three forces are concurrent forces and satisfy the condition for equilibrium.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ A triangle made up of three forces $\vec F_1, \vec F_2$ and $\vec F_3$ as its sides taken in the same order, satisfy the condition for translatory equilibrium.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_b: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
questions.option_c: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
questions.option_d: Both Statement I and Statement II are true

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ Electromagnets are made of soft iron.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ Soft iron has high permeability and low retentivity.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.option_b: A is not correct but R is correct
questions.option_c: A is correct but R is not correct
questions.option_d: Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A

questions.question:
Given below are two statements regarding magnetic materials:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Permanent magnets are preferably made of substances with high retentivity and high coercivity.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Steel is a better material than soft iron for making permanent magnets because it has a smaller area of hysteresis loop.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
questions.option_c: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
questions.option_d: Statement I is false but Statement II is true

questions.question:
Given below are two statements :

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ The electric force changes the speed of the charged particle and hence changes its kinetic energy; whereas the magnetic force does not change the kinetic energy of the charged particle.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ The electric force accelerates the positively charged particle perpendicular to the direction of electric field. The magnetic force accelerates the moving charged particle along the direction of magnetic field.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below :
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
questions.option_c: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
questions.option_d: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ If Oxygen ion $(\text{O}^{2-})$ and Hydrogen ion $(\text{H}^{+})$ enter normal to the magnetic field with equal momentum, then the path of $\text{O}^{2-}$ ion has a smaller radius of curvature than that of $\text{H}^{+}$.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ A proton with same linear momentum as an electron will form a path of smaller radius of curvature on entering a uniform magnetic field perpendicularly.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ are true but $\mathbf{R}$ is NOT the correct explanation of $\mathbf{A}$
questions.option_b: $\mathbf{A}$ is false but $\mathbf{R}$ is true
questions.option_c: $\mathbf{A}$ is true but $\mathbf{R}$ is false
questions.option_d: Both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ are true and $\mathbf{R}$ is the correct explanation of $\mathbf{A}$

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ When a body is projected at an angle $45^{\circ}$, its range is maximum.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ For maximum range, the value of $\sin 2 \theta$ should be equal to one.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.option_b: A is true but R is false
questions.option_c: A is false but R is true
questions.option_d: Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ Two identical balls $A$ and $B$ thrown with same velocity $u$ at two different angles with horizontal attained the same range $R$. If $A$ and $B$ reached the maximum height $h_1$ and $h_2$ respectively, then $R = 4\sqrt{h_1h_2}$.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ Product of said heights $h_1h_2 = \left( \frac{u^2\sin^2\theta}{2g} \right) \cdot \left( \frac{u^2\cos^2\theta}{2g} \right)$.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
questions.option_b: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
questions.option_c: A is true but R is false.
questions.option_d: A is false but R is true.

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ The hot water flows faster than cold water.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Soap water has higher surface tension as compared to fresh water.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
questions.option_c: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_d: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ When a capillary tube is dipped into a liquid, the liquid neither rises nor falls in the capillary. The contact angle may be $0^{\circ}$.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ The contact angle between a solid and a liquid is a property of the material of the solid and liquid as well.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement I is true and Statement II is false
questions.option_b: Statement I is false but Statement II is true
questions.option_c: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
questions.option_d: Both Statement I and Statement II are false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements :

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ When speed of liquid is zero everywhere, pressure difference at any two points depends on equation $P_1 - P_2 = \rho g (h_2 - h_1)$.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ In venturi tube shown $2gh = v_1^2 - v_2^2$.

In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
questions.option_a: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
questions.option_c: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
questions.option_d: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

questions.question: A thin $1\text{ m}$ long rod has a radius of $5\text{ mm}$. A force of $50\pi\text{ kN}$ is applied at one end to determine its Youngâ€™s modulus. Assume that the force is exactly known. If the least count in the measurement of all lengths is $0.01\text{ mm}$, which of the following statements is false ?
questions.option_a: $\frac{\Delta Y}{Y}$ gets minimum contribution from the uncertainty in the length.
questions.option_b: The figure of merit is the largest for the length of the rod.
questions.option_c: The maximum value of $Y$ that can be determined is $2 \times 10^{14}\text{ N/m}^{2}$.
questions.option_d: $\frac{\Delta Y}{Y}$ gets its maximum contribution from the uncertainty in strain.

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion (A)}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason (R)}$.

$\textbf{Assertion (A) :}$ The property of body, by virtue of which it tends to regain its original shape when the external force is removed, is Elasticity.

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ The restoring force depends upon the bonded interatomic and intermolecular force of solid.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :
questions.option_a: (A) is false but (R) is true
questions.option_b: Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_c: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_d: (A) is true but (R) is false

questions.question:
Given below are two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Area under velocity-time graph gives the distance travelled by the body in a given time.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ Area under acceleration-time graph is equal to the change in velocity in the given time.

In the light of the given statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below.
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are False.
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
questions.option_c: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is true.
questions.option_d: Statement I is correct but Statement II is false.

questions.question:
A particle moves along the $x$-axis and has its displacement $x$ varying with time $t$ according to the equation:

$$x = c_0(t^2 - 2) + c(t - 2)^2$$

where $c_0$ and $c$ are constants of appropriate dimensions. Then, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.option_a: the acceleration of the particle is $2(c + c_0)$
questions.option_b: the acceleration of the particle is $2c_0$
questions.option_c: the acceleration of the particle is $2c$
questions.option_d: the initial velocity of the particle is $4c$

questions.question:
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as $\textbf{Assertion A}$ and the other is labelled as $\textbf{Reason R}$.

$\textbf{Assertion A :}$ The Bohr model is applicable to hydrogen and hydrogen-like atoms only.

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ The formulation of Bohr model does not include repulsive force between electrons.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: A is true but R is false
questions.option_b: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.option_c: A is false but R is true
questions.option_d: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A

questions.question:
Consider the nuclear fission:

$$^{20}\text{Ne} \to 2 \, ^{4}\text{He} + ^{12}\text{C}$$

Given that the binding energy per nucleon $(\text{BE}/A)$ of $^{20}\text{Ne}$, $^{4}\text{He}$, and $^{12}\text{C}$ are, respectively, $8.03\text{ MeV}$, $7.07\text{ MeV}$, and $7.86\text{ MeV}$, identify the correct statement:
questions.option_a: 8.3 MeV energy will be released
questions.option_b: energy of 11.9 MeV has to be supplied
questions.option_c: energy of 12.4 MeV will be supplied
questions.option_d: energy of 3.6 MeV will be released

questions.question:
A muon ($\mu^-$) is a negatively charged ($|q| = |e|$) particle with a mass $m_{\mu} = 200 m_e$, where $m_e$ is the mass of the electron and $e$ is the electronic charge. If $\mu^-$ is bound to a proton to form a hydrogen-like atom, identify the correct statements:

(A) The radius of the muonic orbit is 200 times smaller than that of the electron.
(B) The speed of the $\mu^-$ in the $n^{\text{th}}$ orbit is $\frac{1}{200}$ times that of the electron in the $n^{\text{th}}$ orbit.
(C) The ionization energy of the muonic atom is 200 times more than that of a hydrogen atom.
(D) The momentum of the muon in the $n^{\text{th}}$ orbit is 200 times more than that of the electron.

This question contains $\textbf{Statement 1}$ and $\textbf{Statement 2}$. Of the four choices given after the statements, choose the one that best describes the two statements:

$\textbf{Statement 2 :}$ For heavy nuclei, binding energy per nucleon increases with increasing $Z$ while for light nuclei it decreases with increasing $Z$.

questions.option_b: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is a correct explanation for Statement 1
questions.option_c: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is not a correct explanation for Statement 1
questions.option_d: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ The amplitude and phase can be expressed in terms of $x_0$ and $p_0$.

$\textbf{Assertion (A) :}$ With the increase in the pressure of an ideal gas, the volume falls off more rapidly in an isothermal process in comparison to the adiabatic process.

$\textbf{Reason (R) :}$ In isothermal process, $PV = \text{constant}$, while in adiabatic process $PV^{\gamma} = \text{constant}$. Here $\gamma$ is the ratio of specific heats, $P$ is the pressure and $V$ is the volume of the ideal gas.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:

questions.option_b: Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is NOT the correct explanation of (A)
questions.option_c: (A) is false but (R) is true

questions.question:
$\textbf{Statement 1 :}$ The temperature dependence of resistance is usually given as $R = R_0 (1 + \alpha \Delta t)$. The resistance of a wire changes from $100 \, \Omega$ to $150 \, \Omega$ when its temperature is increased from $27^\circ\text{C}$ to $227^\circ\text{C}$. This implies that $\alpha = 2.5 \times 10^{-3} / ^\circ\text{C}$.

$\textbf{Statement 2 :}$ $R = R_0 (1 + \alpha \Delta t)$ is valid only when the change in the temperature $\Delta T$ is small and $(R - R_0) \ll R_0$.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
questions.option_a: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is the correct explanation of Statement 1
questions.option_b: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is true; Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1
questions.option_c: Statement 1 is false, Statement 2 is true
questions.option_d: Statement 1 is true, Statement 2 is false

$\textbf{Reason R :}$ $\text{Least Count} = \frac{\text{Pitch}}{\text{Total divisions on circular scale}}$

questions.option_c: A is correct but R is not correct.

questions.question:
$\textbf{Statement - 1:}$ The variance of first $n$ even natural numbers is $\frac{n^2 - 1}{4}$.

$\textbf{Statement - 2:}$ The sum of first $n$ natural numbers is $\frac{n(n + 1)}{2}$ and the sum of squares of first $n$ natural numbers is $\frac{n(n + 1)(2n + 1)}{6}$.
questions.option_a: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1
questions.option_b: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is not a correct explanation for Statement-1
questions.option_c: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false
questions.option_d: Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:

$\textbf{(a)}$ Mode can be computed from histogram

$\textbf{(b)}$ Median is not independent of change of scale

$\textbf{(c)}$ Variance is independent of change of origin and scale.

Which of these is/are correct?
questions.option_a: only (a)
questions.option_b: only (b)
questions.option_c: only (a) and (b)
questions.option_d: (a), (b) and (c)

questions.question: Consider the set of all lines $px + qy + r = 0$ such that $3p + 2q + 4r = 0$. Which one of the following statements is true?
questions.option_a: The lines are not concurrent
questions.option_b: The lines are concurrent at the point $\left( \frac{3}{4}, \frac{1}{2} \right)$
questions.option_c: The lines are all parallel
questions.option_d: Each line passes through the origin

questions.question:
The lines $L_1: y - x = 0$ and $L_2: 2x + y = 0$ intersect the line $L_3: y + 2 = 0$ at $P$ and $Q$ respectively. The bisector of the acute angle between $L_1$ and $L_2$ intersects $L_3$ at $R$.

$\textbf{Statement-1:}$ The ratio $PR : RQ$ equals $2\sqrt{2} : \sqrt{5}$.

$\textbf{Statement-2:}$ In any triangle, bisector of an angle divides the triangle into two similar triangles.
questions.option_a: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is not a correct explanation for Statement-1.
questions.option_b: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is false.
questions.option_c: Statement-1 is false, Statement-2 is true.
questions.option_d: Statement-1 is true, Statement-2 is true; Statement-2 is a correct explanation for Statement-1.

questions.question:
$\textbf{Statement - 1:}$ The point $A(1, 0, 7)$ is the mirror image of the point $B(1, 6, 3)$ in the line: $\frac{x}{1} = \frac{y - 1}{2} = \frac{z - 2}{3}$.

$\textbf{Statement - 2:}$ The line $\frac{x}{1} = \frac{y - 1}{2} = \frac{z - 2}{3}$ bisects the line segment joining $A(1, 0, 7)$ and $B(1, 6, 3)$.
questions.option_a: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is true; Statement - 2 is not a correct explanation for Statement - 1.
questions.option_b: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is false.
questions.option_c: Statement - 1 is false, Statement - 2 is true.
questions.option_d: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is true; Statement - 2 is a correct explanation for Statement - 1.

questions.question:
Let $A$ and $B$ denote the statements:

$\textbf{A:}$ $\cos \alpha + \cos \beta + \cos \gamma = 0$

$\textbf{B:}$ $\sin \alpha + \sin \beta + \sin \gamma = 0$

If $\cos(\beta - \gamma) + \cos(\gamma - \alpha) + \cos(\alpha - \beta) = -\frac{3}{2}$, then:
questions.option_a: A is false and B is true
questions.option_b: both A and B are true
questions.option_c: both A and B are false
questions.option_d: A is true and B is false

questions.question:
Let $\widehat a$ and $\widehat b$ be two unit vectors such that $|(\widehat a + \widehat b) + 2(\widehat a \times \widehat b)| = 2$. If $\theta \in (0, \pi)$ is the angle between $\widehat a$ and $\widehat b$, then among the statements:

$\textbf{(S1):}$ $2|\widehat a \times \widehat b| = |\widehat a - \widehat b|$

$\textbf{(S2):}$ The projection of $\widehat a$ on $(\widehat a + \widehat b)$ is $\frac{1}{2}$
questions.option_a: Only (S1) is true.
questions.option_b: Only (S2) is true.
questions.option_c: Both (S1) and (S2) are true.
questions.option_d: Both (S1) and (S2) are false.

questions.question:
Between the following two statements:

$\textbf{Statement I :}$ Let $\vec{a}=\hat{i}+2 \hat{j}-3 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{b}=2 \hat{i}+\hat{j}-\hat{k}$. Then the vector $\vec{r}$ satisfying $\vec{a} \times \vec{r}=\vec{a} \times \vec{b}$ and $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{r}=0$ is of magnitude $\sqrt{10}$.

$\textbf{Statement II :}$ In a triangle $ABC, \cos 2A + \cos 2B + \cos 2C \geq -\frac{3}{2}$.
questions.option_a: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
questions.option_b: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
questions.option_c: Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
questions.option_d: Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.

questions.question:
For any vector $\vec{a}=a_{1} \hat{i}+a_{2} \hat{j}+a_{3} \hat{k}$, with $10|a_{i}|<1, i=1,2,3$, consider the following statements:

$\textbf{(A):}$ $\max \{|a_{1}|,|a_{2}|,|a_{3}|\} \leq|\vec{a}|$

$\textbf{(B):}$ $|\vec{a}| \leq 3 \max \{|a_{1}|,|a_{2}|,|a_{3}|\}$
questions.option_a: Only (B) is true
questions.option_b: Only (A) is true
questions.option_c: Neither (A) nor (B) is true
questions.option_d: Both (A) and (B) are true

questions.question: Let $\vec{a}=5 \hat{i}-\hat{j}-3 \hat{k}$ and $\vec{b}=\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+5 \hat{k}$ be two vectors. Then which one of the following statements is TRUE ?
questions.option_a: Projection of $\vec{a}$ on $\vec{b}$ is $\frac{-13}{\sqrt{35}}$ and the direction of the projection vector is opposite to the direction of $\vec{b}$.
questions.option_b: Projection of $\vec{a}$ on $\vec{b}$ is $\frac{13}{\sqrt{35}}$ and the direction of the projection vector is opposite to the direction of $\vec{b}$.
questions.option_c: Projection of $\vec{a}$ on $\vec{b}$ is $\frac{13}{\sqrt{35}}$ and the direction of the projection vector is same as of $\vec{b}$.
questions.option_d: Projection of $\vec{a}$ on $\vec{b}$ is $\frac{-13}{\sqrt{35}}$ and the direction of the projection vector is same as of $\vec{b}$.

questions.question:
Let $\vec{a}=2 \hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}$, and $\vec{b}$ and $\vec{c}$ be two nonzero vectors such that $|\vec{a}+\vec{b}+\vec{c}|=|\vec{a}+\vec{b}-\vec{c}|$ and $\vec{b} \cdot \vec{c}=0$. Consider the following two statements:

$\textbf{(A):}$ $|\vec{a}+\lambda \vec{c}| \geq|\vec{a}|$ for all $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$.

$\textbf{(B):}$ $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{c}$ are always parallel.

Then,
questions.option_a: only (B) is correct
questions.option_b: both (A) and (B) are correct
questions.option_c: only (A) is correct
questions.option_d: neither (A) nor (B) is correct
